Furfuryl alcohol, a significant raw material for production of valuable chemicals, is currently manufactured from selective hydrogenation of furfural relying on polluting copper chromate and expensive noble metal catalysts. On account of inherent advantages, exploiting the low-cost and high-efficient catalysts based on metal-organic framework materials for the selective conversion of furfural is extraordinarily promising. Herein, a series of carbon-supported Cu-nanoparticles (denoted as HK-1-T, T refers to the calcination temperature) can be easily obtained via a one-step pyrolysis conversion of HKUST-1 at large scale. Fascinatingly, the constructed copper catalyst calcined at 350 °C (HK-1-350) exhibits striking activity for selective hydrogenation of furfural, affording complete conversion of furfural and 100% furfuryl alcohol selectivity at 120 °C under 1.5 MPa H2 within 3 h, with the superior cyclic stability at the same time proved by leaching test and reusability experiment. This report provides an attractive route for the highly efficient conversion of furfural to furfuryl alcohol of the industrial production employing non-noble metal catalysts. Graphical abstract Carbon-supported Cu-nanoparticle (HK-1-350) with excellent catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol (100% conversion and 100% selectivity, comparable to precious metal catalysts), had been easily obtained via a one-step pyrolysis conversion of HKUST-1 at large scale. Image, graphical abstract Keywords selective hydrogenation MOF derived catalyst furfural heterogeneous catalysis non-noble metal catalyst Introduction With the view of alleviating the dependence on fossil fuels and improving the environmental problems caused by their large-scale utilization, biomass as a renewable carbon source has become the first choice to replace fossil energy [1–3]. Furfural (FFR) is particularly eye-catching as an important platform molecule that has achieved commercial production, which can be used as a precursor to produce high value-added chemicals with different reaction pathways like hydrogenation, oxidation and so on [4–7]. FFR can easily produce valuable chemicals to mention a few, furfuryl alcohol (FAL), cyclopentanone (CLA), 2-methylfuran (2-MF) etcetera through hydrogenation [8–10]. Among these products, FAL is particularly attractive, due to as an intermediate its easy production of phenolic resin, glass fiber, dispersant and other valuable chemicals [11–13]. However the complex chemical bonds (C=C/C=O) in furfural molecules make it extremely challenging to obtain the target product with high selectivity [14]. Although current industry production of FAL is commonly based on copper chromate catalyst, the utilization of chromium caused serious environmental pollution and aroused widespread concern from human [15]. In order to settle this urgent problem, exploiting highly active chromium-free catalysts used in catalytic selective hydrogenation of FFR is crucial significant. Among them, noble metal catalysts represented by Ru, Pd and Pt show excellent catalytic performance in FFR hydrogenation [16–20]. For instance, Hoseinzadeh et al. prepared UiO-66 supported palladium nanoparticle catalyst which could achieve a yield of 94% FAL in mere about 4 h [18]. Nevertheless, the high cost and scarcity of precious metals limit their application in industrial production, although they exist excellent catalytic performance. Therefore, it is very important to develop non-noble metal catalysts for the industrial production of highly selective hydrogenation of FFR [21–24]. Copper is considered to be one of the most ideal catalysts because the hydrogenation activity of copper to C=O is better than that of C=C, which is conducive to achieving the purpose of selective hydrogenation [25]. Cite a case, Zhang et al. developed a silica-supported copper catalyst prepared by freeze-drying a gel precursor synthesized by ammonia evaporation, which exhibited high catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of FFR [26]. The complex preparation process of the catalysts and the numerous steps still limit their development to a certain extent although these catalysts have good catalytic performance. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging subgroup of crystalline porous materials (CPM), can be constructed in virtue of versatile inorganic metal nodes and abundant organic ligands [27–31]. Given their specific surface area, contrivable and tailorable structure, facile synthesis, MOFs have attracted the exploration enthusiasm of researchers in many fields, such as gas adsorption and separation, fluorescent sensors, drug delivery, biomedicine and heterogeneous catalysis [32–35]. Especially, the preparation of carbon matrix supported metal catalysts using MOFs as sacrificial templates has received much extensive attentions in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [36–38]. Accordingly, we synthesized HKUST-1 adopting hydrothermal method and proceeded one step reduced calcination. Ultimately, carbon coated copper nanoparticles, namely, HK-1-T were obtained as preconceived. In virtue of SEM, TEM, PXRD etc., we analyzed the morphology and found that the morphology of materials was differences at diverse calcination temperatures. At the same time the catalytic performance of them were also studied detailly. Among them, HK-1-350 showed excellent catalytic activity in FFR hydrogenation, in which was FFR completely converted to FAL, and in the meantime over-hydrogenation would not occur under slightly harsh reaction conditions. It provided a new way for the development of low-cost and high-activity FFR liquid phase hydrogenation catalysts. Experimental section Preparation of HKUST-1 (HK-1) The preparation of HKUST-1 was based on the previously reported route [39]. 2.5 g (11.9 mmol) of trimesic acid, 5.0 g (21.5 mmol) of copper nitrate and 125 mL mixed solvent (deionized water, ethanol and DMF in a volume ratio of 1:1:1) were added in a stainless steel reactor. Then stirring until homogeneous solution was formed, aging at 75 °C for 24 h. HKUST-1 was obtained under vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h after washing the blue precipitate 3 times using ethanol by centrifugation at 9000 rpm. Preparation of the catalyst HK-1-T The final calcined products were acquired by calcination the collected HKUST-1 under the N2 atmosphere at different temperatures (300, 350 and 400 °C) with a ramp rate of 2 °C·min−1 for 120 min, which were expressed as HK-1-T (T represents the calcination temperature). Preparation of the comparison catalyst Cu-BDC-600 365.5 mg (2.2 mmol) of terephthalic acid, 483.1 mg (2.0 mmol) of copper nitrate and 40 mL DMF were added in a stainless steel reactor. Then the mixture was sonicated (about 10 min) to form homogeneous solution and next reacted at 120 °C for 24 h. Cu-BDC was obtained under vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h after washing the blue precipitate 3 times using DMF by centrifugation at 9000 rpm. Cu-BDC-600 was acquired by calcination the collected Cu-BDC under the N2 atmosphere at 600 °C with a ramp rate of 2 °C·min−1 for 2 h. The specific characterization (PXRD and SEM) was shown in Supporting Information (Figs. S6 and S7). Catalytic performance evaluation Tests of the FFR hydrogenation were accomplished in a 100 mL high-pressure autoclave (LEHT-2, Shanghai LABE Instrument Co., Ltd). In a concrete step, an amount of catalyst (5.0-50.0 mg) and FFR (0.5 mmol) were placed in EtOH (10 mL) and the reactants were sonicated for 10 minutes to disperse evenly. After transferring to the autoclave, purging with 2 MPa H2 several times and charging the H2 of desired pressure, the reactor temperature was increased to the targeted level and subsequently held for a certain time under stirring (500 rpm). The products were collected after being cooled to room temperature with the water bath at the end of the reaction and analyzed in the gas phase (Shimadzu 2014C). The catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed it several times with H2O and vacuum dried at 60 °C for the next test. According to the following equations, the conversion of FFR and the selectivity of FAL were calculated. Conversion of FFR (%): C ( F F R , % ) = A − B A × 100 % The yield of FAL (%): Y ( F A L , % ) = P A × 100 % The selectivity of FAL (%): S ( F A L , % ) = P A − B × 100 % where A is the added mole of FFR, B is the remained mole of FFR after reaction, P is the mole of product FAL. Results and discussion Material characterization The specific procedure of hydrothermal synthesis of HKUST-1 was illustrated in Fig. 1 . PXRD profiles showed that the as-prepared HKUST-1 shows the same diffraction peak as the simulated one, as presented in Fig. 2 a, confirming that it was successfully synthesized. The SEM image showed that its morphology was consistent with that in the literature, which was a typical octahedron (Fig. S1) [40]. HKUST-1 was then converted into Cu-based catalysts utilizing a heat treatment strategy under an inert atmosphere. Pyrolysis temperature had a great influence on the performance of catalysts and was also a factor that could be easily controlled. In combination with the results of thermogravimetric and VT-PXRD tests (Fig. 2b and Fig. S2), it can be known that the HKUST-1 framework could be stabilized below 300 °C. Therefore, for the end of understanding the influence of pyrolysis temperature in depth, the catalysts at different calcination temperatures (300, 350 and 400 °C) were prepared, and the presence of Cu characteristic peaks at 2θ = 43.2o, 50.4o and 74.1o in all samples was certified by PXRD patterns (Fig. 2c). However, the HK-1-300 catalyst also existed the characteristic diffraction peak of Cu2O at 36.5o (PDF# 65-3288), indicating the presence of Cu2O. Nitrogen adsorption test found that, unlike the micropores of HKUST-1 (Fig. 2d), all the calcined materials had a mesoporous structure (Fig. S3 and Table S1), which was facilitated mass transfer and promoted the catalytic reaction [41]. Investigating the specific chemical states of catalysts, which were calcined at different temperatures, by XPS can demonstrate the existence of C, O and Cu in the material from the survey (Fig. 3 a). The binding energies of HK-1-300 located at around 932.78 eV and 934.67 eV in the 2p spectrum of Cu which were attributed to the 2p3/2 of Cu and Cu2+, and obvious satellite peak observed at 943.7 eV also indicated the existence of CuO (Fig. 3b) [42–44]. In the Cu 2p spectra of HK-1-350 and HK-1-400, only the peak of Cu 2p3/2 at 932.8 eV/932.82 eV can be observed. Since the binding energy of Cu0 and CuI was very similar, we used the Auger spectrogram of Cu to further probe the valence state of Cu. The binding energies of 570.3 eV and 568.7 eV clearly indicated the coexistence of CuI and Cu0 in the catalysts (Fig. S4) [43,45]. Observed from the images of SEM and TEM, all the materials treated with different calcination temperatures maintained micrometer-sized octahedral structures as the original HKUST-1, whereas the difference was that the surface of HK-1-300 became rougher, and after magnification the photos of SEM or TEM, they were both further confirmed that the surface of HK-1-300 was distributed with disorderly flocs (Fig. 4 a, 4d and 5 d). However, the surface of HK-1-350 was distributed with uniformly sized spherical nanoparticles (Fig. 4b and 4e), and it was observed through TEM that the metal particles were evenly dispersed in the carbon-based material without obviously agglomeration (Fig. 5a and 5b). The lattice spacing measured by HRTEM was 0.208 nm to confirm attributing the Cu (111) plane. Therefore, the spherical nanoparticles were identified as metallic Cu species, which was consistent with the results observed by PXRD (Fig. 2). As the calcination temperature further increased to 400 °C, it could be observed that there were not only spherical Cu particles but also some elongated particles on the surface of the octahedron. It could be clearly observed from Fig. 5f that the lattice spacing of 0.209 nm and 0.231 nm was consistent with the crystal plane of Cu (111) and CuO (200) (PDF# 45-0937). This may be due to the large exposed area of the strip-shaped copper particles, and the surface was inevitably more susceptible to oxidation. Catalytic performance evaluation and optimization The hydrogenation property of all the catalysts obtained at different calcination temperatures was first evaluated utilizing FFR hydrogenation as the model reaction. Both trace of FFR conversion (7.76%) and FAL selectivity (8.39%) were presented employing pristine HKUST-1 as the catalyst (HK-1) (Fig. 6 ). HK-1-350 exhibited the supreme catalytic property, as shown in Fig. 6a, and the catalytic performance was slightly reduced as the calcination temperature elevated (HK-1-400). These results indicated that the hydrogenation efficiency was impressionable to the calcination temperature of HKUST-1. Therefore, in the subsequent experiments, HK-1-350 was applicated as the catalyst to optimize the reaction in order to obtain the maximum yield with the minimum energy consumption. A suite of experiments utilizing the different amount of catalyst in the range of 5.0-50.0 mg were carried out and the results shown in Fig. 6b could determine the influence of the catalyst dosage. Accompanied the increase in the feed of catalyst from 5.0 to 15.0 mg, the conversion of FFR can drastically improve from 67.52% to 100% and the selectivity of FAL simultaneously increases from 96.54% to 100%. When the catalyst usage further increased to 20.0 mg or 50.0 mg, the conversion of FFR and the selectivity of FAL remained unchanged, indicating that excessive catalyst had no effect on product distribution and would not lead to over-hydrogenation products. The above experimental results demonstrated that the catalyst was only active on C=O.[ 5 ] But it was worth mentioning that the selectivity of FAL would not be affected even if the catalyst is excessively 3 times. Generally, the distribution of products was greatly affected by hydrogen pressure. Therefore, a succession of experiments adopting the analogous conditions were carried under various pressures (0.5-3.0 MPa) to examine the influence of pressure on the conversion and selectivity, and the screening results shown in Fig. 6c were compiled. There was a distinct improvement of conversion for FFR from 97.24% to 100%, and FAL as a product always had equal selectivity (100%), with the increase in the operating H2 pressure from 0.5 to 1.5 MPa. Further rising the pressure value to 2.0 or 3.0 MPa brought about no change in both the FAL selectivity and FFR conversion, explaining that there was no occurrence of additional side reactions even under high hydrogen pressure. The reaction temperature was a significant indicator to evaluate the performance of a catalyst, therefor the changes in FFR conversion and the selectivity of FAL were investigated using of reaction temperature (110-130 °C) as a variable. As shown in Fig. 6d, the results no doubt showed that a full selectivity of FAL was realized in all three temperature, which illustrated no definite disturbance of temperature for the selectivity of target product. FFR conversion was notably elevated from 82.19% to 100% when the reaction temperature changed from 110 to 120 °C. Furthermore, with the reaction temperature further heated to 130 °C, neither the conversion rate of FFR nor the selectivity of FAL changed, and they were still 100%. We found the reaction time strongly affected the FFR conversion in FFR hydrogenation, and the conversion of FFR increased with time. As shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S6, only 19.54% conversion of FFR was acquired after 0.5 h of reaction, nevertheless a much higher FFR conversion, up to 50.95%, could be reached if the reaction time was prolonged to 1.0 h. Extending the reaction time to 2.5 h, FFR was nearly full converted (99.19%). Further protracting the reaction duration to 3.0 h, complete conversion of FFR was achieved. While of note, the expected product, FAL, always obtained with an entire selectivity and would not decrease with the reaction duration, regardless of whether the reaction time is 0.5 h or 5.0 h (Fig. S6). In addition, we also explored the reason for not achieving 100% selectivity of FAL at a catalyst amount of 5 mg by controlled experiments (Figs. S7-S9). Altogether, it could be determined that using 15.0 mg of HK-1-350 as a catalyst under 120 °C for 3 h could achieve complete conversion of FFR and the selectivity of FAL was 100%. HK-1-350 as the catalyst would not form the product of hydrogenation furan ring even at higher catalyst amount (20/50 mg)/pressure (3 MPa)/temperature (130 °C) or longer reaction time (5 h), and the selectivity to furfuryl alcohol remains unchanged. As we all known that ethanol could be used as a hydrogen donor for the transfer hydrogenation of FFR based on the previous literatures [46–48]. Therefore, toward exploring the role of HK-1-350 in-depth, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation experiments were conducted (Table S2). Changing the atmosphere from hydrogen to air, only 13.04% of FFR could be transformed with a trace selectivity of FAL (3.27%) at 120 °C under ambient pressure in 4.0 h. Using isopropanol instead of ethanol, a very small amount of FFR (3.56%) was converted although the selectivity of FAL could reach 100%. Therefore, it can be determined that the transfer hydrogenation could be negligible in the reaction system. As shown in Fig. 7b, the presence of catalyst determined the efficiency of FFR hydrogenation, without catalyst, a small amount of FFR (3.72%) was converted and the formation of FAL could not be detected by GC. In addition, the impact of the Cu catalyst derived from different Cu-MOF precursor on the FFR hydrogenation activity was evaluated. As a comparison, Cu-BDC with cubic morphology derived Cu catalyst (Cu-BDC-600) was prepared (Figs. S10 and S11), and found to had similar copper content with HK-1-350 by ICP testing (Table S3). It was found that Cu-BDC-600 was unable to sufficiently hydrogenate FFR, only obtaining 87.08% FFR conversion and 71.79% FAL selectivity (Fig. 7b-2). Therefore, we believe that an excessive performance difference due to the difference in copper content can be ruled out at this time. The results clearly show the significance of Cu catalyst preparation with HKUST-1 as the precursor. Comparing the catalytic performance with other catalysts (noble metal/bimetal) in the selective hydrogenation of FFR to FAL also, as shown in Table 1 , the catalytic performance of HK-1-350 was even comparable to that of noble metal catalysts. A leaching experiment was conducted for purpose of illustrating the heterogeneity of the catalyst. With the reaction time lasting 1.5 h in the optimal reaction system, the conversion of FFR was 61.97% with 100% FAL selectivity (Fig. 7b-3). But the solution, filtering out the catalyst, continued react for another 1.5 h giving the FFR conversion almost unchanged (62.6%) with a slightly decreased FAL selectivity (99.26%) (Fig. 7b-4). Recycle Experiment The cycle stability of catalysts is one of the most crucial evaluation consideration for industrial applications. Therefore, HK-1-350 was used as a catalyst to cyclically react three times in the hydrogenation of FFR to observe the changes in catalytic performance. The catalyst was washed with deionized water for several times after each catalytic cycle, as shown in Fig. 8 , complete transformation of FFR could always be achieved with 100% selectivity of FAL for the first two cycles. After third reaction, the selectivity of FAL was slightly reduced (98.73%), and the product was still FAL. Using PXRD to characterize the catalyst before and after the reaction, it was found that, as shown in Fig. S8, the position of the characteristic peak of copper did not shift, which indicated that the catalyst had good application stability. The appearance of the weak peak of Cu2O may be due to the partial oxidation of the Cu surface caused by the long exposure time in the cycle experiment. Conclusion In summary, we have constructed a Cu-based catalyst (HK-1-350) with HKUST-1 as the precursor, existing excellent hydrogenation performance for the selective hydrogenation of furfural, which can realize the complete conversion of furfural to furfuryl alcohol with 100% selectivity under 1.5 MPa H2 at 120°C for 3 h. It is worth mentioning that the selectivity of furfuryl alcohol is not susceptible even increasing the temperature/pressure or increasing the amount of catalyst/reaction time. The results of leaching and recovery experiments proved that it's heterogeneity and has excellent reusability. It could be used as an ideal catalyst for the wholesale production of furfural alcohol from biomass-derived furfural due to its low preparation cost and easy large-scale synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Furfuryl alcohol, a significant raw material for production of valuable chemicals, is currently manufactured from selective hydrogenation of furfural relying on polluting copper chromate and expensive noble metal catalysts. On account of inherent advantages, exploiting the low-cost and high-efficient catalysts based on metal-organic framework materials for the selective conversion of furfural is extraordinarily promising. Herein, a series of carbon-supported Cu-nanoparticles (denoted as HK-1-T, T refers to the calcination temperature) can be easily obtained via a one-step pyrolysis conversion of HKUST-1 at large scale. Fascinatingly, the constructed copper catalyst calcined at 350 °C (HK-1-350) exhibits striking activity for selective hydrogenation of furfural, affording complete conversion of furfural and 100% furfuryl alcohol selectivity at 120 °C under 1.5 MPa H2 within 3 h, with the superior cyclic stability at the same time proved by leaching test and reusability experiment. This report provides an attractive route for the highly efficient conversion of furfural to furfuryl alcohol of the industrial production employing non-noble metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Budget MOF-derived catalyst to realize full conversion from furfural to furfuryl alcohol
